description.narrative:
Projektet kommer att fasas ut i september 2015. Under utfasningen avser AMREF SRHR främja och konsolidera en hållbar utveckling av ungdomars sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa. För att ta itu med viktiga områden som är relevanta för ökad jämställdhet och stärkt SRHR-perspektiv kommer detta arbete att innebära bärkraftigt kapacitetshöjande och säkrade positiva förändringar inom offentliga strukturer och det civila samhällets organisationer.
Summary The project will be phased out by September 2015. During the phaseout period, the AMREF SRHR for young people project intends to consolidate and promote sustainability of young people's sexual and reproductive health concepts and services and structures. In order to address key areas that intend to enhance both the gender and SRHR perspective, this will involve building sustainable capacity and securing positive changes within government structures and civil society organisations.

The project will be phased out by September 2015. During the phaseout period, the AMREF SRHR for young people project intends to consolidate and promote sustainability of young people's sexual and reproductive health concepts and services and structures. In order to address key areas that intend to enhance both the gender and SRHR perspective, this will involve building sustainable capacity and securing positive changes within government structures and civil society organisations.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights project has been implemented through four main Components namely: 1)Youth Friendly Services ( YFS), 2) Advocacy and Policy Analysis 3) Capacity building and 4)Health systems strengthening. through these approaches a number of activities have been implemented that have resulted in significant acheivements during the period 2010- 2015: 1) The programme has reached 282,598 Young people with SRHR education through Health talks, youth forums and SRR education sessions. 2) Cumulatively throughtout the project period, the number of Young people utilising Sexual and Reproductive Health youth friendly services such as Voluntary counselling and testing, family planning and Sexual Transmitted Infections management has increased from 13,787 ( 7765M: 6022F) in 2010/2011 to 200,300 ( 70,000M:130,300F) in 2014/2015. 3) Cumulatively, the number of Young people reached with SRH services in youth friendly Health facilities in 772,778 ( 406,306M: 366,472F). This includes Young people in and out of school, Young people living with HIV/AIDS, Young people with disabilities and key populations ( MSM, Lesbians, CSW) in Iringa and DSM. 4) The project also provided psychosocial services to young people for improving their social well-being to cope with adolescence behaviours. More than 841 vulnerable groups ( Young people with hearing and other disabilities, Young people living with HIV/AIDS and Children in remand homes) and key populations ( MSH, Lesbians) in Iringa and DSM were reached with psychosocial counselling services, SRH rights services and information. 5) Young people were equipped with knowledge and skills that would enable them to adopt positive behaviours towards SRHR in order to improve their health status. 6) The project in collaboration with the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare and selected consultants facilitated the process of reviewing the National Policy Guideline ( NPG) in Reproductive and Child Health, and the document was submmitted to the MOHSW for the final approval processes in December 2015. 7) The project has renovated and supplied Equipment to 13 Health facilities. This included 5 health facilities in Iringa, ¤ Health facilities in Kinondoni and 4 Health facilities in Ilala Municpal Councils. The renovation work was judged successfully as per the bills of quantities. 8) The handing over of the renovated Health facilities was officially launched by the Ambassador of Sweden on 23rd April 2015 at Tandale Dispensary. The final handing over of all the 13 facilities was conducted between July- September 2015 in all Municipal Councils.
An external evaluation of the project that was conducted in December 2014 concluded that the project design was highly relevant in relation to the Tanzanian policies and strategies concerning sexual and reproductive health, specificallyfor adolescents. The implementation of the project was built on the national strategies and guidelines and the national curriculum were used for the training. The project design and implementation have also been in line with applicable Swedish strategies for development cooperation and in particular regarding the cooperation with Tanzania.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
